instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8545: What is LP8545? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
This laptop was working ok, video and backlight.
I opened this laptop to replace a cap and now when I tested, has video (can see blinking folder) but no backlight. I checked led driver <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP> and has a hole. I replaced it with new one and check for short before and after the diode. No short. After replacment I do have 25 at <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>. I check this on diode and on lvds connector, but still no backlight, only blinking folder.
I tested with another working screen and lcd cable and no backlight. What is next to check?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: PWM signal to <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: PWM pin2 - 2.16V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: That is all fine and 25V would also mean there should be backlight. Check on diode mode if pins 38-40 actually have continuity to the other end of an LCD cable.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I dont have opened screen to check but I tested with another screen and LCD cable assembled and no backlight. Replace LVDS connector is worth it?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I just took a lcd cable I have for 2012 model and put it on this board and I tested 3 backlight pins and all them goes to the other end of LCD cable. In the other end I found 2 pines. Pin2 and pin3.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> high? Do a PRAM reset and see if PWM signal goes higher than 2.16V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I did pram and smc reset. Still no backlight, but PWM goes higher yes.

PWM  - 2.45V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.1V
After <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> - 24.82V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Diode mode on all LED return lines at the LCD connector?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
With lcd and screen conected pins 

31-36  0.671/0L

Red to ground - 0.671
Black to ground - 0L

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Duke, something more to try?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and connect pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> directly to 3V, like to <CAPACITOR>C9711</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I did what you told me. Now in pin2 of <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP> I have 3.28V, and after <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> I still have the same 24.82V. Still no backlight. Obviously it is not PWM problem. What more can could be?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I took again another macbook 2010 and put there the motherboard and I affirm the same. I have video, I see the folder blinking but missing backlight with another screen and LCD cable.
It is board issue, but what more could be?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I have no idea. Compare the 25V to another 15" machine. It could be bad solder or dead <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP> again. Check resistors around the <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP> and check if no components were moved/blown off while replacing <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: But need to understand what screen expect from board to turn on LEDs? Which signals? In laptops expect 12-19V, PWM and enable. And in apple?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
25V is not that low but it could be higher.
On a working 2010 15" BKL output is 33V and LED return lines are 3.2V so that puts about 30V across the LEDs

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
And how do you think these LED driver got burn? This is second macbook pro for 2 weeks. One is 2010 15, and another 2012 15
Both of them working good, video, backlight. I just opened them to replace a cap and after that backlight is gone. In both cases I found hole in <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP>
I dont know what wrong I do...why this led driver just got damage. In first case board 2012 I just replaced it and it works good.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I have no idea, but you are shoving 2012 connectors into 2010 boards.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: About PWM, when it change from 2.2V to 2.5V this should increase VLED from 25V to 30V?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: No idea, 2.5V seems low. We can talk about this all day but you need to swap the <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP> and check all resistors.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Will replace <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP> again and will compare with another board I have here for parts.
It is possible to test screen connecting 30V to VLED directly? Will turn on the leds or it is no enought? This way also I can check if leds turn on at 27,28 or 29V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Negative to LED return lines and positive to the BKL Vout. LEDS should light at about 30V. But do this with a variable power supply and go up from 20V till they light up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Sorry, you mean I have to put all 6 return lines to negative? And <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> to power supply. 20-30V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Why do you even want to mess with this? This is not going to fix the board. I gave you the correct voltages from the board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Finally I got this board working. Resume: I found <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP> damage and no backlight. After I replaced this IC with new one I got only 25V and no backlight. I replaced it again with new one same provider and again only 25V and no backlight. I replaced it again and the same. Always check carrefuly how this chip is solder and I solder this chip perfectly.

Then I took this chip from my board for parts and now backlight works and I have 33V

New chip from SEE-IC I got is written on it: VM08AD   45-EXTF. This chip doesnot work for me. I got only 25V with this chip. Could be fake chip? Or not exact part number they sent to me?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: These chips have en EEPROM inside. Maybe they are programmed for something. A blank default EEPROM normally works.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Never find a not working new chip?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I don't buy these new chips, enough donor boards in the pile.
